g.text: While viewing a live video, users can see a real-time stream of comments
- Users can see a real-time stream of comments
- Users can see comments posted before they started watching
- Support very large numbers of users
- Show other user's comments in real-time
- ownerName (opt, can also cache userId: username mapping in redis)
handle comments with websockets, send following message payloads:
- comment is published to redis pub/sub channel for that videoId
- If user scrolls up and wants to see comments from before they joined, they can
send "requestHistoricalComments(page, size)", server responds with an array of
- User sends "listenForComments(videoId)" payload to server, server subscribes
to redis pub/sub channel for that videoId and forwards all new comments to user
can also use to cache userId: username mapping
- What if there's a hot video with tons of comments?
- Bottlenecks: rendering all comments in UI, a single redis channel (which may be handled by a single
instance, not sure) may not be able to handle the traffic
- Can implement virtual sharding across redis channels like videoId-1/3, videoId-2/3, videoId-3/3,
comments are randomly published to one channel, each comment service node subscribes to a single channel
and only forwards that 1/n subset of comments to their connected users. For thousands of comments
per second, no user will know the difference, and it makes the volume of data manageable for their device
